If for some reason, the Queen were to parachute into Quebec City with James Bond, maybe then the separatists would be happy. Until then, her face will do nicely as campaign fodder for the sovereigntist Parti Québécois. The party released a campaign ad and made statements this week infused with what might easily have been dismissed as good old-fashioned anti-monarchism, had it not been for the fact that Her Majesty was actually standing in for a different target altogether: the federal government in Ottawa.

It had become rather uncommon in the last two decades for the Queen to be at all associated with a federal political party, or much with Canadian life at all. Before the Harper Conservatives took on the task of bringing the monarchy back into the fold, the last time anyone really noticed the Queen was maybe when they saw her portrait at a Winnipeg Jets game the day before they moved the team to Phoenix. That's now changed. The Queen has long been an easy symbol for the sovereignty movement to assert Quebec's place in Canada, or as one of historical subjugation. But "it never really went beyond that, I think, in terms of the overall debate, until this current government decided to really make it a powerful symbol in its own representation of Canada", says Philippe Lagassé, assistant professor of public and international affairs at the university of Ottawa.

That's because for a while, the Queen's image was downplayed at the expense of other ones, such as the flag, (which lost its union flag component in 1965), peacekeeping, or healthcare – all of which became Canadiana de rigeur for a generation or two, and most of which were either spearheaded or put in place by the Liberal party. It was Pierre Trudeau, after all, who pushed for a patriated constitution (within which the crown's role in Canada is actually solidified). And when he pirouetted behind Her Majesty in 1977, it became an iconic image not of disrespect, but of Trudeau's own self-perpetuated public persona as the modernist lighthearted scamp. This was a new Canada.

Fast forward a bit and let's say you're the newly elected Conservative party and you're setting out to not only govern, but establish yourself as a legitimate Canadian institution in your own right. What's left for you to appropriate for political capital, now that the Liberals – and Trudeau especially – took it all? How do you get to a newer Canada? Rather than downplay the monarchy, the Conservatives have "tried to recast it as a really thorough Canadian institution. It's no longer about being part of a British empire, it's no longer being part of a larger British collective, but it's that monarchy has been an institution that has governed Canada since its outset," says Lagassé. "Today you see the rhetoric change quite significantly where it's no longer about a British connection, but it's about the Queen of Canada, the Canadian Crown and that emphasis."

The Queen "is Canadian," immigration minister Jason Kenney told the House of Commons on 4 June as he noted the jubilee. "All of the proud associations we share with the monarchy are Canadian through and through … Every day we Canadians enjoy the protection and benediction of that crown and mantle, and every day we open this House, praying for our sovereign lady, the Queen."

What is old is new again, and the Queen has once again a spot in the Canadian consciousness as a cause championed by the Harper government – now not just a high-profile institution, but a partisan one. And, judging by the advert, it's working. When Marois was asked to elaborate on the anti-monarchist reference in her party's new ad, she mentioned that a painting by Quebecois artist Alfred Pellan at the department of foreign affairs in Ottawa had been replaced with a portrait of the Queen. It was more than just an point of annoyance; it was an affirmation of exactly what the Conservatives have worked hard to cultivate. "I would think the government has better things to do than that," Marois said.

Or not.
